title: R44392
content: The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. It can only be used towards qualified health insurance and is refundable and advanceable. Taxpayers can claim the credit even with little or no federal income tax liability. Eligibility criteria apply. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. It can only be used towards qualified health insurance and is refundable and advanceable. Taxpayers can claim the credit even with little or no federal income tax liability. Eligibility criteria apply. The two groups eligible for the HCTC are recipients of benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program and individuals aged 55-64 receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). TAA provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to international trade. If a DOL investigation confirms workers' claim, they are certified for TAA benefits and services, including the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC). Eligibility for HCTC is based on receiving Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) or unemployment insurance (UI). TRA is a cash payment for workers in TAA training who have exhausted UI benefits. Workers can receive up to 130 weeks of combined UI and TRA. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is available to workers collecting Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) or unemployment insurance (UI). Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA) provides a wage supplement for workers aged 50 and older who secure qualified employment at a lower wage. RTAA pays 50% of the wage difference for up to two years. Alternative Trade Adjustment Assistance (ATAA) is a similar wage-insurance program. Workers become eligible for HCTC on the first day of a month if they received an eligible TAA benefit. To be eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), individuals must receive TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits. Workers certified for TAA but receiving only job-search assistance are not eligible. PBGC benefits are available to those who worked for a firm with an insured defined-benefit pension plan taken over by PBGC. The PBGC pays pensions to former workers when plans are terminated to protect participants' interests or if employers can't stay in business. PBGC pensions make individuals eligible for the HCTC if they are at least 55 years old and not yet on Medicare. The HCTC program has eligibility limitations. Eligibility for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is restricted for individuals enrolled in certain health plans or programs, including those maintained by employers, Medicare Part B, FEHBP, Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare Part A, Tricare, and for those who are incarcerated. Individuals are not eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) if they are incarcerated or can be claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer. Eligible taxpayers can use the HCTC for health insurance covering their spouse and dependents. Children of divorced or separated parents are considered dependents of the custodial parent. Family members may receive the HCTC for up to two years after the taxpayer becomes eligible for Medicare. An eligible taxpayer can claim the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) for up to two years after specific events, such as becoming eligible for Medicare, divorce, or death. The HCTC can only be used for 11 categories of qualified health insurance, with four options being automatically qualified health plans that individuals can choose without state involvement. Coverage options for the Health Coverage Tax Credit include COBRA, group health plans through a spouse's employer, individual health insurance, VEBA-funded coverage, and state-qualified health plans like state-based continuation coverage and state high-risk pools. State-qualified health plans, including those offered through state high-risk pools or state-based arrangements, must provide specific consumer protections to qualifying individuals. State-qualified health plans must offer protections to qualifying individuals, including guaranteed issue coverage, no denial based on preexisting conditions, and equal premiums for all applicants. Benefits for qualifying individuals must be the same as or substantially similar to benefits for others, with certain types of coverage not considered qualified health insurance. This includes accident or disability income insurance, liability insurance, workers' compensation insurance, and other specific types of coverage. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) program is administered by the IRS with involvement from federal and state agencies like the Department of the Treasury (Treasury), Department of Labor (DOL), and Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). Treasury administers the advance payment system for HCTC, providing it monthly to coincide with insurance premium payments. DOL helps identify eligible individuals and coordinates the One-Stop Career Center system. The One-Stop Career Center system assists job seekers with services and information about benefits like the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC). State workforce agencies (SWAs) administer unemployment and Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) benefits. SWAs mail HCTC information packets to eligible TAA beneficiaries, including an HCTC eligibility certificate. The PBGC also identifies potential HCTC beneficiaries. The PBGC identifies potential HCTC beneficiaries and provides their information to the IRS. The IRS sends program kits to eligible individuals for claiming the tax credit. Taxpayers with qualified health insurance can claim the credit when filing their tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. The HCTC is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full eligible amount. The HCTC is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full eligible amount even with little or no tax liability. It does not affect eligibility for other tax credits except for the premium tax credit under the Affordable Care Act. In 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling approximately $52.3 million. In 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling approximately $52.3 million. Taxpayers claiming the credit must complete Form 8885 and provide proof of payment for qualified health insurance. The credit amount reduces taxes owed and is refundable if it exceeds the tax liability. Individuals register with the HCTC program to receive advance payments by enrolling in a qualified health insurance plan. The program confirms eligibility, sends an invoice for the taxpayer's share of the premium, and upon payment, Treasury covers 100% of the premium. The HCTC program covers 100% of the premium for individuals' health insurance plans, with 27.5% from the individual and 72.5% from Treasury.
